0.text: The person that I would like to nominate is somebody you won't have heard of

6.text: I met Alice when I was a curate in an inner city parish in Nottingham.

11.text: She was quite elderly by the time that I met her.

14.text:
She'd lived and worked and served
there for many years.

18.text: She did have quite a sense of humour and she was quite a force to be reckoned with even when I met her.

23.text:
The reason I am nominating
her is because in a very different way

27.text:
she too showed some of those qualities
that I admire so much of perseverance and resilience and courage.

34.text: I also had quite a personal inspirational moment with her

37.text: because when she was actually dying of cancer she called me to her bedside

42.text:
and she wanted to
give me really quite an odd gift.

47.text: And the few words that we exchanged, she made it clear that she felt she'd done her time

54.text: she had served her generation faithfully and there was a real sense of her now saying, 'It's your time'.

62.text: She hadn't been able to be ordained, but there was a real sense of her passing on the baton.

68.text: Well, all I know is that if I can continue half her spirit of courage and resilience and perseverance

76.text: I think I want to nominate Alice also because I want to honour all those like her

81.text:
who actually did phenomenal
things with their lives -

84.text:
gave their lives in amazing ways - but for very little
recognition.

89.text: So, to Alice and all those like her, today I want to honour you.
